Chebyshev Circles

Blueprint API Docs Dependency Graph GitHub

Rotated Roots of Unity and Chebyshev Polynomials

When the N-th roots of unity are rotated by angle φ and projected onto the real axis and then taken to be the roots of a polynomial, after scaling by 2N-1 the polynomial formed from these projections equals the N-th Chebyshev polynomial of the first kind plus a φ-dependent constant.

Main Theorem

theorem rotated_roots_yield_chebyshev (N : ℕ) (φ : ℝ) (hN : 0 < N) :
  ∃ (c : ℝ), scaledPolynomial N φ = Polynomial.Chebyshev.T ℝ N + C c
Construction:
  • Projected roots: cos(φ + 2πk/N) for k = 0, ..., N-1
  • Unscaled polynomial: P(x) = ∏(x - cos(φ + 2πk/N))
  • Scaled polynomial: S(x) = 2N-1 · P(x)
  • Result: S(x) = TN(x) + c(φ)

Research Paper

Publication-ready mathematics paper (14 pages) with complete proofs in classical notation.

Traditional exposition targeting a general mathematical audience at graduate level.

Read Paper →

Why This Connection Matters

This theorem reveals a surprising geometric interpretation of Chebyshev polynomials. Rather than defining them via recurrence relations or cosine composition, we can construct them by taking N equally-spaced points on the unit circle, rotating them by any angle, projecting onto the real axis, building the polynomial with these projections as roots, and scaling by 2N-1. The result is always TN(x) plus a constant.

This provides a bridge between discrete geometry (roots of unity on the circle), harmonic analysis (discrete orthogonality relations), and polynomial theory (Chebyshev polynomials).

Proof Strategy

The verification establishes that rotated roots and Chebyshev roots have identical power sums (except the zeroth), which by Newton's identities implies they generate polynomials differing only by a constant term. The power sum equality relies on discrete orthogonality of complex exponentials over N-th roots of unity, the discrete analog of continuous Fourier orthogonality.

Getting Started

Prerequisites: Lean 4 (v4.25.0-rc2), basic familiarity with polynomials, complex numbers, and trigonometric identities.

Clone the repository and build the project:

git clone https://github.com/e-vergo/ChebyshevCircles.git
cd ChebyshevCircles
lake exe cache get
lake build

Explore the Blueprint for an interactive map of the formalization, check the API Documentation for detailed proofs, or view the Dependency Graph to understand the proof structure.

Why This Connection Matters

This theorem reveals a surprising geometric interpretation of Chebyshev polynomials. Rather than defining them via recurrence relations or cosine composition, we can construct them by taking N equally-spaced points on the unit circle, rotating them by any angle, projecting onto the real axis, building the polynomial with these projections as roots, and scaling by 2N-1. The result is always TN(x) plus a constant.

This provides a bridge between discrete geometry (roots of unity on the circle), harmonic analysis (discrete orthogonality relations), and polynomial theory (Chebyshev polynomials).

Proof Strategy

The verification establishes that rotated roots and Chebyshev roots have identical power sums (except the zeroth), which by Newton's identities implies they generate polynomials differing only by a constant term. The power sum equality relies on discrete orthogonality of complex exponentials over N-th roots of unity, the discrete analog of continuous Fourier orthogonality.

Getting Started

Prerequisites: Lean 4 (v4.25.0-rc2), basic familiarity with polynomials, complex numbers, and trigonometric identities.

git clone https://github.com/e-vergo/ChebyshevCircles.git

lake exe cache get

input.new_string:
Proof Strategy

The verification establishes that rotated roots and Chebyshev roots share identical power sums for all positive degrees, which by Newton's identities implies they generate polynomials differing only by a constant term. This approach reduces the geometric claim to an algebraic invariant (power sums), then applies classical polynomial algebra to reach the conclusion.

Critical Proofs

Power Sum Invariance (powerSumCos_invariant): The cornerstone of the entire proof. This establishes that ∑cosm(φ + 2πk/N) is independent of the rotation angle φ for all m ≥ 1. The proof exploits the fact that cos(θ) = (eiθ + e-iθ)/2, converting cosine powers into sums of complex exponentials. These exponential sums telescope to zero by discrete orthogonality unless specific divisibility conditions hold, yielding the φ-independence. Without this result, there would be no connection between rotated roots and Chebyshev polynomials.

Discrete Orthogonality (ChebyshevOrthogonality module): Proves that ∑k=0N-1 exp(2πikm/N) = 0 for 0 < m < N and equals N when m = 0 or N divides m. This is the discrete analog of continuous Fourier orthogonality on the circle. The proof uses properties of geometric series and the fact that N-th roots of unity satisfy ωN = 1. This orthogonality is what causes most terms in the power sum expansion to vanish, leaving only the φ-independent contributions. It connects harmonic analysis (orthogonality relations) to polynomial root behavior.

Newton's Identities (NewtonIdentities module): Establishes the relationship between power sums of roots and elementary symmetric polynomials (coefficients). Specifically, if two monic polynomials have roots with matching power sums S1, S2, ..., SN, then the polynomials have identical coefficients except possibly the constant term. This is the bridge that converts power sum equality into polynomial equality up to a constant. The formalization handles the recursive structure of Newton's identities and proves the converse direction needed: power sum agreement implies coefficient agreement. This classical result from polynomial algebra is indispensable for connecting root properties to polynomial identity.

Chebyshev Circles

Blueprint API Docs Dependency Graph GitHub

Rotated Roots of Unity and Chebyshev Polynomials

Rotating the N-th roots of unity by angle φ and projecting them onto the real axis yields N points. The polynomial with these projections as roots, when scaled by 2N-1, equals the N-th Chebyshev polynomial of the first kind plus a constant that depends on φ.

Main Theorem

theorem rotated_roots_yield_chebyshev (N : ℕ) (φ : ℝ) (hN : 0 < N) :
  ∃ (c : ℝ), scaledPolynomial N φ = Polynomial.Chebyshev.T ℝ N + C c

View theorem statement in API docs →

Construction:
  • Projected roots: cos(φ + 2πk/N) for k = 0, ..., N-1 (blueprint §2)
  • Unscaled polynomial: P(x) = ∏(x - cos(φ + 2πk/N)) (blueprint §3)
  • Scaled polynomial: S(x) = 2N-1 · P(x) (blueprint §3)
  • Result: S(x) = TN(x) + c(φ) (blueprint §1)
